title: Temporary Activity visa (subclass 408) - Australian Government endorsed events (COVID-19 Pandemic event)
raw_text: ===== main placeholder ========================================== This visa is closed to new applicants. The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa closed to all applications on 1 February 2024. For more information, see ​ Closure of the Pandemic Event We will continue to assess all applications lodged before 1 February 2024.​​ Temporary Activity visa (subclass 408) - Australian Government endorsed events (COVID-19 Pandemic event) Page Content ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​The Australian Government introduced the Pandemic Event visa in April 2020 to allow temporary visa holders to remain in Australia lawfully while the border was closed. It also addressed labour shortages in critical sectors in the local economy. Now that Australia’s borders are open and temporary visa holder numbers in Australia have returned to pre-COVID-19 levels, the Pandemic Event visa is no longer required. About this visa Details What this visa lets you do Details This is a temporary visa. It allows you to: remain temporarily in Australia to work travel outside Australia and return while your COVID-19 Pandemic Event visa is in effect. Cost Details From AUD405.00. There is also a charge for each family member added to a lodged application. You may have to pay other costs, such as health assessments, police certificates, other certificates or tests. You are responsible for making the necessary arrangements. Eligibility Details Applications made after 2 September 2023 and before 1 February 2024 Details If you applied on or after 2 September 2023 and before 1 February 2024, you may only be eligible for a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa if one of the following is true: You held a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa that had 28 days or less remaining when you lodged your application. You held a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa that ceased within 28 days of lodging your application When you lodged your application, you must have been working or intending to work in Australia, and provided evidence of your employment or offer of employment. Evidence of employment must confirm: the dates of your employment the sector you were working or intending to work in a description of your position and duties. Evidence could include payslips, a contract, or a letter from your employer. If you applied for a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa on or after 2 September 2023 and before 1 February 2024, and did not hold a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa when you lodged your application, you were not eligible for this visa. This will result in your application being refused, which may have adverse consequences for you. You should: explore visa options to find a different visa more suitable to your circumstances or make arrangements to depart Australia check what you need to do if your visa is expiring or has expired Applications made after 21 February 2022 and before 2 September 2023 Details The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa changes announced by the Government on 2 September 2023 will not affect undecided COVID-19 Pandemic event visa applications lodged on or after 21 February 2022, but before 2 September 2023. These applications will continue to be assessed. Applications made before 21 February 2022 Details The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa changes announced by the Government on 2 March 2022 or 2 September 2023 will not affect undecided COVID-19 Pandemic event visa applications lodged before 21 February 2022. These applications will continue to be assessed. Be able to support yourself and any dependants Details You must have enough money to support yourself and any dependant family members with you in Australia. Health Details You and any family members who applied for the visa with you must meet our health requirements . This means you may need to undergo a health check. We will contact you if you need to undergo a health check. Character Details You and family members aged 16 years and over who applied for the visa with you must meet our character requirements We might also ask that other family members meet the requirement. We will contact you if you need to undergo character checks. Have adequate health insurance Details You must have adequate health insurance for your stay in Australia. Be a genuine temporary entrant Details You cannot use our temporary visa program to maintain ongoing residence in Australia. We must be satisfied that you have a genuine intention to stay here temporarily. When assessing your application, we will consider your: situation in Australia and in your home country immigration history compliance with visa conditions other relevant matters. Have paid back debt to the Australian government Details You must have no outstanding debts to the Australian Government or have arranged to repay any outstanding debts to the Australian Government before this visa can be granted. Visa applicants Details The COVID-19 Pandemic Event visa closed to all applications on 1 February 2024. See what you can and must do if you have lodged a visa application. Status Updates Details You can check the status of your visa application, upload new information or respond to requests for information in your ImmiAccount Your application could take longer if you need character or health checks (including x-rays), if you need to provide more information, or if your application is incomplete. Travel Details If you leave Australia before we make a decision on your application, make sure you hold a visa that allows you to return to Australia. Check your conditions and the expiry of your current visa in VEVO Learn more about visa expiry Health exams Details If you didn’t have health examinations before you applied, we will let you know if you need them. To learn more, visit Health requirements Health insurance Details It is a mandatory condition of your visa that you maintain adequate health insurance during your stay in Australia. Attach more information Details If you did not attach all documents when you applied, attach them as soon as possible in your ImmiAccount We might also ask you to provide more information. Stay Lawful Details If you are in Australia, make sure you stay lawful by holding a visa that remains in effect while we process your application. If you were in Australia when you applied for this visa, you may be granted a: Bridging visa A (BVA) if you held a substantive visa when you applied Bridging visa C (BVC) if you did not hold a substantive visa when you applied. If your current visa expires before we decide your application, the bridging visa will come into effect. You can stay in Australia on the bridging visa while we process your visa application. You can't re-enter Australia on a BVA or BVC. There is no right of return on these visas and they will cease on departure. Learn more about visa expiry Check what conditions might apply to your bridging visa or the visa you have applied for with our condition checker Newborn children Details If your child was born after you applied for this visa find out what you need to do by visiting You had a child Mistakes on your application Details Let us know as soon as you can if you made a mistake on your application. Complete Form 1023 Notification of incorrect answers (168KB PDF) . Then attach it to your application in ImmiAccount Help with your application Details Let us know if you want, or no longer want, someone to: receive your correspondence - complete Form 956a Appointment or withdrawal of an authorised recipient (301KB PDF) provide immigration advice - complete Form 956 Advice by a migration agent/exempt person of providing immigration assistance (308KB PDF) act for you - let us know in writing by uploading your advice to your application in ImmiAccount To find out more about appointing or withdrawing a nomination, visit Who can help with your application Tell us if things change Details Things you need to let us know about after you have applied might include: changes to your phone number, email, address or passport changes to your marital or de facto status the birth of a child you want to withdraw your application. You must withdraw your application, if your circumstances have changed since you applied for a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa, and you no longer need this visa. If you do not withdraw your application, this visa may be granted and as a result, any other substantive visa that you may hold will cease at the time we grant your COVID-19 Pandemic event visa. See how to tell us if your situation changes Visa outcome Details The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa can only be granted to primary applicants in Australia. We will let you know our decision in writing. If we grant your visa, we will tell you: your visa grant number the date your visa starts your visa conditions, if applicable. Keep a copy of the decision. If we refuse your visa, we will tell you: why we refused the visa whether you have a right to a review of the decision. Visa holders Details Workers’ rights Details Temporary visa holders with permission to work in Australia are protected by Australian workplace law. See your workplace rights and entitlements To see your conditions for work, use VEVO Your obligations Details You and your family members must comply with all visa conditions and Australian laws. Tell us if things change Details Things you need to let us know about when you have this visa include: changes to your phone number, email, address or passport changes to your relationship status the birth of a child. See how to let us know if there is a change in your situation See how long you can stay Details To see how long you can stay and when you must leave, use VEVO Travelling on your visa Details You can travel outside Australia and return multiple times, as long as your COVID-19 Pandemic Event visa is in effect. Time spent outside Australia does not extend the period of stay in Australia. To see your period of stay, use VEVO Proving you have a visa Details To prove you have a visa and to show your visa conditions to someone, use VEVO You can request your international movement records online, for more information visit Requesting travel records If your visa has expired or is about to expire Details You should ensure that you hold a valid visa if you wish to stay in Australia. Becoming unlawful may impact your ability to visit Australia in the future. You may apply for a different visa if eligible, or make arrangements to depart Australia before your visa expires. If you remain in Australia without a visa, you risk being detained and removed. You may also incur a debt to the Australian Government for the cost of your removal. To see if your visa has expired already, use VEVO If your COVID-19 Pandemic event visa has already expired, and you have not applied for a different visa, you: must make arrangements to depart Australia may be barred from re-applying for a different visa in Australia may be subject to a re-entry ban For more information, see your visa is about to expire or has expired If your COVID-19 Pandemic event visa has already expired, you can get help from the Status Resolution Service

===== main placeholder ==========================================

This visa is closed to new applicants.The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa closed to all applications on 1 February 2024. For more information, see ​Closure of the Pandemic Event.We will continue to assess all applications lodged before 1 February 2024.​​

This visa is closed to new applicants.

This visa is closed to new applicants.

The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa closed to all applications on 1 February 2024. For more information, see ​Closure of the Pandemic Event.

The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa closed to all applications on 1 February 2024. For more information, see ​
Closure of the Pandemic Event
.

We will continue to assess all applications lodged before 1 February 2024.​​

We will continue to assess all applications lodged before 1 February 2024.​​

# Temporary Activity visa (subclass 408) - Australian Government endorsed events (COVID-19 Pandemic event)

Temporary Activity visa (subclass 408) - Australian Government endorsed events (COVID-19 Pandemic event)
Page Content

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​The Australian Government introduced the Pandemic Event visa in April 2020 to allow temporary visa holders to remain in Australia lawfully while the border was closed. It also addressed labour shortages in critical sectors in the local economy.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​The Australian Government introduced the Pandemic Event visa in April 2020 to allow temporary visa holders to remain in Australia lawfully while the border was closed. It also addressed labour shortages in critical sectors in the local economy.

Now that Australia’s borders are open and temporary visa holder numbers in Australia have returned to pre-COVID-19 levels, the Pandemic Event visa is no longer required.

Now that Australia’s borders are open and temporary visa holder numbers in Australia have returned to pre-COVID-19 levels, the Pandemic Event visa is no longer required.
​

## About this visa

About this visa
Details

### What this visa lets you do

What this visa lets you do
Details

This is a temporary visa. It allows you to:

This is a temporary visa. It allows you to:
- remain temporarily in Australia to work
remain temporarily in Australia to work
- travel outside Australia and return while your COVID-19 Pandemic Event visa is in effect.
travel outside Australia and return while your COVID-19 Pandemic Event visa is in effect.

### Cost

Cost
Details

From AUD405.00.

From AUD405.00.

There is also a charge for each family member added to a lodged application.

There is also a charge for each family member added to a lodged application.

You may have to pay other costs, such as health assessments, police certificates, other certificates or tests. You are responsible for making the necessary arrangements.

You may have to pay other costs, such as health assessments, police certificates, other certificates or tests. You are responsible for making the necessary arrangements.

### Eligibility

Eligibility
Details

#### Applications made after 2 September 2023 and before 1 February 2024

Applications made after 2 September 2023 and before 1 February 2024
Details

If you applied on or after 2 September 2023 and before 1 February 2024, you may only be eligible for a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa if one of the following is true:

If you applied on or after 2 September 2023 and before 1 February 2024, you may only be eligible for a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa if one of the following is true:
- You held a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa that had 28 days or less remaining when you lodged your application.
You held a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa that had 28 days or less remaining when you lodged your application.
- You held a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa that ceased within 28 days of lodging your application
You held a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa that ceased within 28 days of lodging your application

When you lodged your application, you must have been working or intending to work in Australia, and provided evidence of your employment or offer of employment. Evidence of employment must confirm:

When you lodged your application, you must have been working or intending to work in Australia, and provided evidence of your employment or offer of employment. Evidence of employment must confirm:
- the dates of your employment
the dates of your employment
- the sector you were working or intending to work in
the sector you were working or intending to work in
- a description of your position and duties.
a description of your position and duties.

Evidence could include payslips, a contract, or a letter from your employer.

Evidence could include payslips, a contract, or a letter from your employer.

If you applied for a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa on or after 2 September 2023 and before 1 February 2024, and did not hold a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa when you lodged your application, you were not eligible for this visa. This will result in your application being refused, which may have adverse consequences for you. You should:

If you applied for a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa on or after 2 September 2023 and before 1 February 2024, and did not hold a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa when you lodged your application, you were not eligible for this visa. This will result in your application being refused, which may have adverse consequences for you. You should:
- explore visa options to find a different visa more suitable to your circumstances or make arrangements to depart Australia
explore visa options to find a different visa more suitable to your circumstances or make arrangements to depart Australia
- check what you need to do ifyour visa is expiring or has expired.
check what you need to do if
your visa is expiring or has expired
.

#### Applications made after 21 February 2022 and before 2 September 2023

Applications made after 21 February 2022 and before 2 September 2023
Details

The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa changes announced by the Government on 2 September 2023 will not affect undecided COVID-19 Pandemic event visa applications lodged on or after 21 February 2022, but before 2 September 2023.

The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa changes announced by the Government on 2 September 2023 will not affect undecided COVID-19 Pandemic event visa applications lodged on or after 21 February 2022, but before 2 September 2023.

These applications will continue to be assessed.

These applications will continue to be assessed.

#### Applications made before 21 February 2022

Applications made before 21 February 2022
Details

The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa changes announced by the Government on 2 March 2022 or 2 September 2023 will not affect undecided COVID-19 Pandemic event visa applications lodged before 21 February 2022.

The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa changes announced by the Government on 2 March 2022 or 2 September 2023 will not affect undecided COVID-19 Pandemic event visa applications lodged before 21 February 2022.

These applications will continue to be assessed.

These applications will continue to be assessed.

### Be able to support yourself and any dependants

Be able to support yourself and any dependants
Details

You must have enough money to support yourself and any dependant family members with you in Australia.

You must have enough money to support yourself and any dependant family members with you in Australia.

### Health

Health
Details

You and any family members who applied for the visa with you must meet ourhealth requirements. This means you may need to undergo a health check.

You and any family members who applied for the visa with you must meet our
health requirements
. This means you may need to undergo a health check.

We will contact you if you need to undergo a health check.

We will contact you if you need to undergo a health check.

### Character

Character
Details

You and family members aged 16 years and over who applied for the visa with you must meet ourcharacter requirements.

You and family members aged 16 years and over who applied for the visa with you must meet our
character requirements
.

We might also ask that other family members meet the requirement.

We might also ask that other family members meet the requirement.

We will contact you if you need to undergo character checks.

We will contact you if you need to undergo character checks.

### Have adequate health insurance

Have adequate health insurance
Details

You must have adequate health insurance for your stay in Australia.

You must have adequate health insurance for your stay in Australia.

### Be a genuine temporary entrant

Be a genuine temporary entrant
Details

You cannot use our temporary visa program to maintain ongoing residence in Australia.

You cannot use our temporary visa program to maintain ongoing residence in Australia.

We must be satisfied that you have a genuine intention to stay here temporarily.

We must be satisfied that you have a genuine intention to stay here temporarily.

When assessing your application, we will consider your:

When assessing your application, we will consider your:
- situation in Australia and in your home country
situation in Australia and in your home country
- immigration history
immigration history
- compliance with visa conditions
compliance with visa conditions
- other relevant matters.
other relevant matters.

### Have paid back debt to the Australian government

Have paid back debt to the Australian government
Details

You must have no outstanding debts to the Australian Government or have arranged to repay any outstanding debts to the Australian Government before this visa can be granted.

You must have no outstanding debts to the Australian Government or have arranged to repay any outstanding debts to the Australian Government before this visa can be granted.

## Visa applicants

Visa applicants
Details

The COVID-19 Pandemic Event visa closed to all applications on 1 February 2024.

The COVID-19 Pandemic Event visa closed to all applications on 1 February 2024.

See what you can and must do if you have lodged a visa application.

See what you can and must do if you have lodged a visa application.

### Status Updates

Status Updates
Details

You can check the status of your visa application, upload new information or respond to requests for information in yourImmiAccount.

You can check the status of your visa application, upload new information or respond to requests for information in your
ImmiAccount
.

Your application could take longer if you need character or health checks (including x-rays), if you need to provide more information, or if your application is incomplete.

Your application could take longer if you need character or health checks (including x-rays), if you need to provide more information, or if your application is incomplete.

### Travel

Travel
Details

If you leave Australia before we make a decision on your application, make sure you hold a visa that allows you to return to Australia.

If you leave Australia before we make a decision on your application, make sure you hold a visa that allows you to return to Australia.

Check your conditions and the expiry of your current visa inVEVO.

Check your conditions and the expiry of your current visa in
VEVO
.

Learn more aboutvisa expiry.

Learn more about
visa expiry
.

### Health exams

Health exams
Details

If you didn’t have health examinations before you applied, we will let you know if you need them.

If you didn’t have health examinations before you applied, we will let you know if you need them.

To learn more, visitHealth requirements.

To learn more, visit
Health requirements
.

### Health insurance

Health insurance
Details

It is a mandatory condition of your visa that you maintain adequate health insurance during your stay in Australia.

It is a mandatory condition of your visa that you maintain adequate health insurance during your stay in Australia.

### Attach more information

Attach more information
Details

If you did not attach all documents when you applied, attach them as soon as possible in yourImmiAccount.

If you did not attach all documents when you applied, attach them as soon as possible in your
ImmiAccount
.

We might also ask you to provide more information.

We might also ask you to provide more information.

### Stay Lawful

Stay Lawful
Details

If you are in Australia, make sure you stay lawful by holding a visa that remains in effect while we process your application.

If you are in Australia, make sure you stay lawful by holding a visa that remains in effect while we process your application.

If you were in Australia when you applied for this visa, you may be granted a:

If you were in Australia when you applied for this visa, you may be granted a:
- Bridging visa A (BVA) if you held a substantive visa when you applied
Bridging visa A (BVA) if you held a substantive visa when you applied
- Bridging visa C (BVC) if you did not hold a substantive visa when you applied.
Bridging visa C (BVC) if you did not hold a substantive visa when you applied.

If your current visa expires before we decide your application, the bridging visa will come into effect. You can stay in Australia on the bridging visa while we process your visa application. You can't re-enter Australia on a BVA or BVC. There is no right of return on these visas and they will cease on departure.

If your current visa expires before we decide your application, the bridging visa will come into effect. You can stay in Australia on the bridging visa while we process your visa application. You can't re-enter Australia on a BVA or BVC. There is no right of return on these visas and they will cease on departure.

Learn more aboutvisa expiry.

Learn more about
visa expiry
.

Check what conditions might apply to your bridging visa or the visa you have applied for with ourcondition checker.

Check what conditions might apply to your bridging visa or the visa you have applied for with our
condition checker
.

### Newborn children

Newborn children
Details

If your child was born after you applied for this visa find out what you need to do by visitingYou had a child.

If your child was born after you applied for this visa find out what you need to do by visiting
You had a child
.

### Mistakes on your application

Mistakes on your application
Details

Let us know as soon as you can if you made a mistake on your application.

Let us know as soon as you can if you made a mistake on your application.

CompleteForm 1023 Notification of incorrect answers (168KB PDF). Then attach it to your application inImmiAccount.

Complete
Form 1023 Notification of incorrect answers (168KB PDF)
. Then attach it to your application in
ImmiAccount
.

### Help with your application

Help with your application
Details

Let us know if you want, or no longer want, someone to:

Let us know if you want, or no longer want, someone to:
- receive your correspondence - completeForm 956a Appointment or withdrawal of an authorised recipient (301KB PDF)
receive your correspondence - complete
Form 956a Appointment or withdrawal of an authorised recipient (301KB PDF)
- provide immigration advice - completeForm 956 Advice by a migration agent/exempt person of providing immigration assistance (308KB PDF)
provide immigration advice - complete
Form 956 Advice by a migration agent/exempt person of providing immigration assistance (308KB PDF)
- act for you - let us know in writing by uploading your advice to your application inImmiAccount.
act for you - let us know in writing by uploading your advice to your application in
ImmiAccount
.

To find out more about appointing or withdrawing a nomination, visitWho can help with your application.

To find out more about appointing or withdrawing a nomination, visit
Who can help with your application
.

### Tell us if things change

Tell us if things change
Details

Things you need to let us know about after you have applied might include:

Things you need to let us know about after you have applied might include:
- changes to your phone number, email, address or passport
changes to your phone number, email, address or passport
- changes to your marital or de facto status
changes to your marital or de facto status
- the birth of a child
the birth of a child
- you want to withdraw your application.
you want to withdraw your application.

You must withdraw your application, if your circumstances have changed since you applied for a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa, and you no longer need this visa. If you do not withdraw your application, this visa may be granted and as a result, any other substantive visa that you may hold will cease at the time we grant your COVID-19 Pandemic event visa.

You must withdraw your application, if your circumstances have changed since you applied for a COVID-19 Pandemic event visa, and you no longer need this visa. If you do not withdraw your application, this visa may be granted and as a result, any other substantive visa that you may hold will cease at the time we grant your COVID-19 Pandemic event visa.

See how to tell us if yoursituation changes.

See how to tell us if your
situation changes
.

### Visa outcome

Visa outcome
Details

The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa can only be granted to primary applicants in Australia.

The COVID-19 Pandemic event visa can only be granted to primary applicants in Australia.

We will let you know our decision in writing.

We will let you know our decision in writing.

If we grant your visa, we will tell you:

If we grant your visa, we will tell you:
- your visa grant number
your visa grant number
- the date your visa starts
the date your visa starts
- your visa conditions, if applicable.
your visa conditions, if applicable.

Keep a copy of the decision.

Keep a copy of the decision.

If we refuse your visa, we will tell you:

If we refuse your visa, we will tell you:
- why we refused the visa
why we refused the visa
- whether you have a right to a review of the decision.
whether you have a right to a review of the decision.

## Visa holders

Visa holders
Details

### Workers’ rights

Workers’ rights
Details

Temporary visa holders with permission to work in Australia are protected by Australian workplace law. See yourworkplace rights and entitlements.

Temporary visa holders with permission to work in Australia are protected by Australian workplace law. See your
workplace rights and entitlements
.

To see your conditions for work, useVEVO.

To see your conditions for work, use
VEVO
.

### Your obligations

Your obligations
Details

You and your family members must comply with all visa conditions and Australian laws.

You and your family members must comply with all visa conditions and Australian laws.

### Tell us if things change

Tell us if things change
Details

Things you need to let us know about when you have this visa include:

Things you need to let us know about when you have this visa include:
- changes to your phone number, email, address or passport
changes to your phone number, email, address or passport
- changes to your relationship status
changes to your relationship status
- the birth of a child.
the birth of a child.

See how to let us know if there is achange in your situation.

See how to let us know if there is a
change in your situation
.

### See how long you can stay

See how long you can stay
Details

To see how long you can stay and when you must leave, useVEVO.

To see how long you can stay and when you must leave, use
VEVO
.

### Travelling on your visa

Travelling on your visa
Details

You can travel outside Australia and return multiple times, as long as your COVID-19 Pandemic Event visa is in effect.

You can travel outside Australia and return multiple times, as long as your COVID-19 Pandemic Event visa is in effect.

Time spent outside Australia does not extend the period of stay in Australia.

Time spent outside Australia does not extend the period of stay in Australia.

To see your period of stay, useVEVO.

To see your period of stay, use
VEVO
.

### Proving you have a visa

Proving you have a visa
Details

To prove you have a visa and to show your visa conditions to someone, useVEVO.

To prove you have a visa and to show your visa conditions to someone, use
VEVO
.

You can request your international movement records online, for more information visitRequesting travel records.

You can request your international movement records online, for more information visit
Requesting travel records
.

### If your visa has expired or is about to expire

If your visa has expired or is about to expire
Details

You should ensure that you hold a valid visa if you wish to stay in Australia. Becoming unlawful may impact your ability to visit Australia in the future.

You should ensure that you hold a valid visa if you wish to stay in Australia. Becoming unlawful may impact your ability to visit Australia in the future.

You may apply for a different visa if eligible, or make arrangements to depart Australia before your visa expires.

You may apply for a different visa if eligible, or make arrangements to depart Australia before your visa expires.

If you remain in Australia without a visa, you risk being detained and removed. You may also incur a debt to the Australian Government for the cost of your removal.

If you remain in Australia without a visa, you risk being detained and removed. You may also incur a debt to the Australian Government for the cost of your removal.

To see if your visa has expired already, useVEVO.

To see if your visa has expired already, use
VEVO
.

If your COVID-19 Pandemic event visa has already expired, and you have not applied for a different visa, you:

If your COVID-19 Pandemic event visa has already expired, and you have not applied for a different visa, you:
- must make arrangements todepart Australia
must make arrangements to
depart Australia
- may be barred from re-applying for a different visa in Australia
may be barred from re-applying for a different visa in Australia
- may be subject to are-entry ban.
may be subject to a
re-entry ban
.

For more information, seeyour visa is about to expire or has expired.

For more information, see
your visa is about to expire or has expired
.

If your COVID-19 Pandemic event visa has already expired, you can get help from theStatus Resolution Service.

If your COVID-19 Pandemic event visa has already expired, you can get help from the
Status Resolution Service
.
